Expounded by Åšramaá¹‡a Shi Huiyuan of Jingying Temple in the Sui Dynasty
Next, extensively explaining the inconceivable Buddha realm above. The realm refers to nirvÄá¹‡a. Following transformation, it shows cessation, but the real
virtues always abide;
Although the real virtues abide, the wondrous quiescence is beyond characteristics, thus it is called inconceivable.
This virtue is difficult to manifest. Now, relying on the transformed cessation to enter and reveal it, wishing to make sentient beings learn from the Buddha to abandon characteristics and enter it.
There are four parts in this:

First, relying on the place of cessation to reveal the true nirvÄá¹‡a; second, relying on the time of cessation to reveal the true nirvÄá¹‡a; third, relying on the adorned forest to reveal the true nirvÄá¹‡a; fourth, relying on the cessation of the body to reveal the realization and entry.
There are two parts in the place:
First, relying on the city to break with non-Buddhists and clarify that the great nirvÄá¹‡a is permanently blissful, self, and pure;
Second, relying on the forest to clarify that the great nirvÄá¹‡a is permanently blissful, self, and pure.
In the city, the lion first asks, the meaning of the question is threefold:
First, asking why he abandoned the six great cities and came here;
Second, he asks why the TathÄgata is in this nirvana;
Third, he asks why the TathÄgata enters nirvana in this filthy and evil place of KuÅ›inagara.
The Buddha answers separately below, first responding to the latter question.
You should not say it is filthy, evil, narrow, or small, briefly refuting his words, you should say it is subtle and wonderful, teaching him with principle.
Why is it so? The explanation below.
The place where buddhas and bodhisattvas practice is a brief explanation with a doctrinal statement, like a lowly person and below, three analogies are used to illustrate, followed by a conclusion.
I recall in the past and below answers the second question, with three further explanations:
First, in the past he once heard the Buddha's name at this place, practiced the ten wholesome deeds, and came here to repay the kindness of the earth;
Second, he once cultivated the four immeasurables at this place;
Third, he once saw the Buddha and gave rise to the aspiration for enlightenment at this place, so he came here.
I first left below, in response to the initial question, clarifies that it was in order to pursue the various non-Buddhist paths that he abandoned the six and left here.
First, it clarifies abandoning the six, and later, in KuÅ›inagara, it overthrows the false and reveals the correct. First, it is specific, and later, it is concluded.
Within the specific, there are three:
First, it clarifies the six masters going to KuÅ›inagara first, increasing the world's false views;
Second, I saw this below, the TathÄgata arrived later, overturning the false and revealing the correct.
Third, At that time, the six masters said this below, it clarifies the various non-Buddhists grasping the false and confusing the correct, and the TathÄgata's refutation.
The first section can be understood.
In the second section, first, it clarifies the TathÄgata's pity for these sentient beings deluded by false teachers, widely requesting the bodhisattvas to roar like great lions.
Although in emptiness below, it clarifies the reason for gathering the bodhisattvas' roars.

The lion's roar is said to be all below shows what it roars. Speaking of impermanence, bliss distinguishes the dharmas of birth and death. Speaking of the Buddha's permanence, etc. reveals the dharmas of nirvana.
In the third section, first it clarifies the Tathagata's refutation of wrong views and manifestation of the correct.
The non-Buddhist teachings say that if one says the Tathagata is permanent, blissful, and has self below clarifies the non-Buddhists abandoning wrong views and returning to the correct.
There are two parts in the former:
First, refuting the non-Buddhists' view of the self as identical to the dharmas; second, The six teachers say form is not the self below refutes their view of the self as different from the dharmas.
In the former, first it refutes the self using the six sense faculties, then it refutes the self using the five skandhas.
In the refutation using the sense faculties, first it refutes wrong attachments. The true view seen by the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas below reveals the correct principle.
In the refutation of wrong views, there are two parts:ğŸ”½First, the non-Buddhists establish the self, which the Tathagata refutes;
Second, the non-Buddhists question the Buddha, to which the Tathagata responds.
In the first part, the non-Buddhists first establish their self, saying, Gautama has a self, and I also have a self, mixing up their falsehood with the truth.
Below, they distinguish the characteristics of the self, speaking about the eyes among the six sense faculties.
The seer is called the self - the principle is established through explanation, next with a metaphor, and finally combining it.
Below, the Buddha refutes it, saying, The seer being called the self, this principle is not so - he summarizes it and refutes it.
Why? - below he explains, with three further explanations:
First, the function of a single sense faculty is not simultaneous, refuting the definite existence of the self.
A person in one direction uses all six sense faculties simultaneously - distinguishing the characteristics of the metaphor.
If there definitely is - below he investigates the principle being the same as the metaphor.
If in a single sense faculty one is not able - below, using the principle to seek the metaphor, refuting the definite existence of the self.
Second, the function of the sense faculties is not always the same, refuting the definite existence of the self.
The metaphor you cite, although it has passed a hundred years, the cause of seeing is no different - distinguishing the characteristics of the metaphor.
If the eye faculty... below, it investigates the dharmas that are the same as the analogy, clarifying the knowledge of no-self.
The three faculties are used to decisively refute the definite existence of self.
Because the person faces differently, one sees inside and outside distinguishes the characteristics of the analogy.
If the eye faculty... below, it investigates the dharmas that are the same as the analogy.
If one does not see... below, it clarifies that the dharmas contradict the analogy, refuting the definite existence of self.
Below, the non-Buddhists reversely investigate the TathÄgata, If there is no self, who can see?

Below, the Buddha explains, first clarifying that the combination of the four things is called seeing, next clarifying the absence of self, and below clarifying that sentient beings mistakenly see self.
The above refutes the false and reveals the correct, which can be understood.
Below, it refutes the definite existence of self based on the five aggregates.
The text is divided into four parts:
First, it refutes the false; second, it reveals the correct; third, it again refutes the false; fourth, it again reveals the correct.
In the beginning, it first refutes based on the aggregate of form and classifies the remaining four.
Within the form aggregate, first it refutes the self, then it refutes permanence and so forth.
In refuting the self, If form is the self, this is also not so raises [the view] to refute it in general.
Why is it so? below extensively reveals its non-so, refuting it with five phrases.
If form is the self, it should not be ugly is one refutation;
Why is there also a difference in the four castes? is the second refutation;
Why is it subject to others? is the third refutation;
The faculties are incomplete is the fourth refutation;
Why not become a god and experience hell? and so forth is the fifth refutation.
If one cannot below concludes the refutation in general.
Below it refutes permanence and so forth, and classifies the remaining aggregates, the text is all understandable.
The above refutes the false, The Tathagata eternally below reveals the correct meaning, Furthermore, form below again refutes the false, The Tathagata's body below again reveals the correct meaning.
Next, it refutes the view that the self is different from the aggregates.
It first refutes the wrong views and then reveals the correct principle.
In the refutation of wrong views, there are four pairs of [arguments and counter-arguments].

The first is that the non-Buddhist path, based on the previous refutation, establishes the self as different from the aggregates, saying, Form up to consciousness are all not the self. The self is all-pervading, just like space.
The Buddha refutes this below, with three further explanations.
The first is a refutation based on the view, saying, If it pervades, one should not say that the self's objects are not seen. This is a refutation based on the original [claim].
If the self is all-pervading, originally and always pervading, then form in all places should always be seen, and one should not say that the self does not see it at first.
If it is not seen at first but seen later, then it was originally non-existent, and thus impermanent. How can it be said to be all-pervading?

The second is a refutation based on the destinies, saying, If the self is all-pervading, it should have a body in the five destinies. This is a refutation that requires [the self] to be present everywhere.

Fearing they would establish a fixed self, he further refutes, If it is complete, in the five realms one should each receive retribution. How can it be said that one turns away from the three evil paths and receives a human or heavenly body?
Third, he refutes based on oneness and difference.
First, he makes two determinations, Is it one or many?
If it is one, there would be no father and son and so on, refuting based on oneness.
If I am many and so on, refuting based on being many.

If it is many and pervasive, the self of this person pervades the body of that person, and the self of that person pervades the body of this person. The five faculties, karma, and wisdom of all sentient beings should all be the same, and there should be no differences.
Fearing they would establish sameness, he further refutes.

If they are the same, how can it be said that faculties are complete or incomplete? Refuting sameness of faculties. Good karma and evil karma refutes sameness of karma. Distinctions of foolishness and wisdom refutes sameness of wisdom.
The second non-Buddhist uses words to rescue the meaning.
The self is boundless, while dharmas and non-dharmas each have their own limits.
Because of their differences, one who cultivates good dharmas obtains a good body, while one who practices non-dharmas obtains an evil body, thus there are distinctions.
Below, the Buddha refutes him.
If it is so, then the self is not all-pervading, using difference to investigate pervasiveness.
If the self is all-pervading, using pervasiveness to investigate difference.

If it is all-pervading, then this self reaches the other body, and that self also reaches this person's body, therefore the good person should also have evil, and the evil person should also have good karma.
Since good and evil are common, how can the bodily retribution be different?
If it is not so, below, concludes that it is not all-pervading.
The third non-Buddhist uses a metaphor to rescue his argument.
It is like a room with a hundred thousand lamps lit, the lamps are different but the light is common.
The self is also like this, like the light pervading everywhere.
Cultivating good and doing evil is like a lamp being separate and not mixed together.
Below, the Buddha refutes it.
Saying 'I am like a lamp,' this is not so - refuting it in general.
Why is it so? - extensively revealing the meaning of non-so.
There are three phrases:
First, light exists due to conditions and increases with the lamp, I am not like this - not suitable as a metaphor.
Second, light comes from the lamp and abides in a different place, I am not like this - not suitable as a metaphor.
Third, light and darkness are together, I am not like this - not abiding together with non-self, for this reason it is not suitable as a metaphor.
In the text, the first phrase light and darkness are together briefly raises the point.
Why is it so? - explaining below.
If one lamp is lit, it is not clear - directly discussing the light of the lamp abiding together with darkness. Many lamps make it clear - using many to show few.

If the first lamp is destroyed, the later lamp is not needed - using the first to refute the later. If the later lamp is needed, it is known that the first co-abides - using the later to prove the former.
The fourth is the non-Buddhist refuting the TathÄgata.
If there is no self, who creates good and evil?
Below, the Buddha first refutes with four meanings.
If the self is the creator, how can it be called permanent?
If it is permanent, how can it sometimes create good and sometimes create evil? This is one refutation.
If it sometimes creates, how can it be said that the self is boundless? This is the second refutation.
If the self is the creator, how can it engage in evil? This is the third refutation.
If the self is the knower, how can it give rise to doubt that sentient beings have no self? This is the fourth refutation.
For this reason and below, he concludes the refutation in general.
Above, he refutes the wrong; below, he reveals the right meaning, clarifying the Buddha's permanence, bliss, self, purity, and emptiness. The text is evident and understandable.
The above is the first part, refuting non-Buddhist teachings and revealing the correct.
If it is said that the TathÄgata is permanent, blissful, self, and pure... below, clarifying how non-Buddhists abandon non-Buddhist teachings and return to the correct.
The above extensively clarifies the Buddha's arrival in KuÅ›inagara to refute non-Buddhist teachings and reveal the correct.
For these reasons, I... and below, summarizing it in general.
Next, using the forest location to reveal nirvÄá¹‡a, first distinguishing, then concluding.
In the distinction, there are four parts:
First, borrowing the eight trees to symbolize the eight cultivations;
Second, using the fact that sentient beings protect the ÅšÄla forest to make disciples learn to protect the Dharma;
Third, using the four heavenly kings to protect the ÅšÄla forest to immediately make them protect the Dharma;
Fourth, using the fact that the flowers and fruits of this forest are always luxuriant to benefit sentient beings to illustrate how they are already able to benefit the Å›rÄvaka assembly.
For these reasons... and below concludes.
Next, using the time of extinction to reveal nirvÄá¹‡a.
In this, first using the second month to reveal it.
The lion first asks, and below the Buddha answers, first distinguishing, then concluding.
The four sentences in the specific section are:

First, it clarifies that many people in the second month give rise to the four inverted minds of permanence, bliss, self, and purity. The Buddha destroys them and reveals the permanence, bliss, self, and purity of the TathÄgata. He first destroys the inversion of permanence, then bliss, self, and purity.
Second, it illustrates the TathÄgata's two kinds of Dharma bodies, namely the true and the responsive.
Third, he does not enter nirvana in winter, showing that the wise do not delight in the TathÄgata's impermanence and extinction;
Entering nirvana in the second month shows that the wise love and delight in the TathÄgata's permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Fourth, using the events of planting and so forth in the second month to illustrate the disciples cultivating various wholesome dharmas.
There are four in this:
First, using planting as a metaphor for sentient beings hearing the Dharma, giving rise to the mind, and planting various wholesome roots;
Second, the rivers and oceans filling up, as a metaphor for the bodhisattvas gathering like clouds from the ten directions;
Third, the beasts giving birth and suckling, as a metaphor for the disciples planting various wholesome roots;
Fourth, the blooming and flourishing of flowers and fruits, as a metaphor for the disciples cultivating the flowers of the seven factors of enlightenment and attaining the fruits of the four paths.
Next, on the fifteenth day, it symbolizes nirvana.
The lion first asks,
The four times such as birth are all on the eighth day, why is nirvana alone on the fifteenth day?
Below, the Buddha first praises and then explains.
There are three points in the explanation:
First, on the fifteenth day, the moon has no waning or waxing, which shows that the Buddha's nirvana has no waning or waxing;
Second, on the fifteenth day, the moon is full and perfect for eleven things, which shows that the Buddha's virtues are complete and he benefits sentient beings in eleven ways;

Third, I truly do not enter and below, based on the first section, it clarifies that the Buddha is not extinguished, and foolish people think he is extinguished, first the Dharma and then the analogy.
Below this, the third is based on the decorated forest to show nirvana.
The lion first asks, and below the Buddha explains.
The virtuous person manifests the place, therefore it is called adorned.
It is precisely to clarify the Buddha Vehicle. The disciples are immeasurable, but six people are briefly mentioned, together with the Buddha there are seven.
In each person, the Buddha first explains, and then the lion's roar is used to express the disciples' understanding.
In explaining ÅšÄriputra, first praising his wisdom, and below toward enemies and friends praising his mental practices.
In wisdom there are ten phrases, great wisdom is the general.

Swiftly entering into principle is called sharp wisdom, quickly understanding phenomena is called swift wisdom, freely eliminating hindrances is called liberation wisdom, thoroughly illuminating principle is called profound wisdom, extensively understanding worldly meanings is called broad wisdom, exhausting the ocean of Buddhist teachings is called unsurpassed wisdom.
Therefore the sÅ«tra says: Excluding only the Buddha, World-Honored One, all types of sentient beings, wishing to compare ÅšÄriputra's wisdom and vast learning, cannot reach even one-sixteenth of it.

Below the Buddha answers it, first clarifying that he will not remain.

Later it is made clear that he wishes to leave. In clarifying that he will not remain, there are altogether twenty-seven more reasons. The text extensively manifests that he will not remain, but the essentials are summarized into four:
The first explanation uses reason to refute, saying, If all dharmas are without abiding, how can you request the Buddha to abide?
The second explanation has six further explanations, extensively clarifying that the TathÄgata's abiding has completely ended, and one should not request him to abide.

The fourth explanation has eight further explanations, extensively citing all that are ultimately without affairs, revealing the Buddha's non-abiding. First, it extensively cites, and later it uses this to compare with the Buddha.
Before, it clarified non-abiding, and below it clarifies wanting to leave.
The TathÄgata enters this great samÄdhi, the cave of deep dhyÄna concentration. Because the assembly does not see it, it is called entering nirvÄá¹‡a.
This then uses the person to reveal the actual realization, causing people to learn it.
A question is asked:
Above it was said that the TathÄgata is ultimately always in the world and does not enter nirvÄá¹‡a, but now why is it said that he has already entered nirvÄá¹‡a without abiding?
The explanation is as follows:
The virtues of the Buddha have four kinds of aspects.
The first is the aspect of being in the world, always in the world without ever disappearing for a moment;
the second is the aspect of abiding in tranquility, never emerging for a moment;
the third is the aspect of reversing tranquility and giving rise to function, manifesting transformations according to beings;
the fourth is the aspect of ceasing function and returning to tranquility, abandoning transformations and returning to the true.

The previous [teaching] relied on the first aspect to show that he is in the world and ultimately does not disappear, but now it is based on the fourth, therefore it is said that he has already entered nirvÄá¹‡a without abiding.

From not from within or without up to this point, the third major section extensively reveals the Dharma of realization.
From here on is the fourth section, which encourages cultivation and entry, extensively revealing the practice of realization.
How is this different from the second section above, that it needs to be discussed again?

In this section, it discusses the practice in terms of individuals, this is the second difference.
There are four levels in this section:
The first teaches cultivating the three, which is the practice of entering realization on the first ground and above;
Next, it teaches cultivating the ten, which is the practice of entering realization from the stage of the seeds up to the stage of understanding and practice;

As the Buddha told Cunda in the past... and below, it teaches cultivating the four kinds of virtues that transform karma, which is the practice of entering realization within the stage of goodness;ğŸ”½The Lion's Roar said:
The Buddha said:
All sentient beings possess Buddha-nature, which should be cultivated - below this, it encourages those who are constantly sinking to cultivate the holy path as the practice leading to realization.
There are two parts in the beginning:

Second, What kind of bhiká¹£us can cut off the ten... and below teaches the practice leading to entry, which is similar in meaning to the second cultivation of the ten in the following.

First, it clarifies that it is called formless because it is far removed from ten kinds of characteristics. First it raises, then lists, and finally concludes, which can be understood.

Teaching cultivation and entry, first briefly, next extensively, and finally concluding with praise.

Next, specifically, and finally concluding.
In the extensive explanation, first asking What is called concentration, wisdom, and equanimity? asking about the characteristics of practice.
Concentration is... and below, refuting the meaning of practice, first refuting its concentration, and later categorizing wisdom and equanimity.
In the refutation of concentration, Concentration is samÄdhi, all have it, why speak of cultivating samÄdhi? Taking the general to refute the specific.
Among the mental factors, there is a certain number, all beings have it, taking this general to refute the specific cultivation.
If the mind is... and below, taking the specific to refute the general.
Grasping onto a single dharma as samÄdhi, and considering the rest to be non-samÄdhi, is called a difficult point.
Dharmas have general and specific aspects. The general is called the object, and the specific is called the practice.
The object and practice should be comprehensive, but in order to distinguish the general and specific, they are given different names based on their hidden and manifest aspects.
General dharmas can be known through their common characteristics, so they are called the object from the perspective of the mind that cognizes them;
Specific dharmas can only be understood through contemplation and investigation, so they are called the practice from the perspective of the mind that practices them.
In this text, first, based on the general object, the difficulty of grasping the specific and making it comprehensive is discussed.
If the mind is one-pointed, it is called samÄdhi. This establishes a principle, which is grasping the specific.
If it is an object other than that, it is not called samÄdhi. This refutes the views of others.
How can a different object and scattered agitation be called concentration?
This is the difficulty of making it comprehensive.
If it is not concentrated, it is not omniscience. This is a difficulty based on concentration and knowledge.
The objects of a scattered mind are thoughts and consciousness. How can they be called knowledge?
This is raised as a fault for the desire and concentration.
If it is not omniscience, how can it be called concentration? This is a difficulty regarding concentration based on wisdom.
If it cannot give rise to wisdom, how can it be called concentration?
Moreover, if it is not accompanied by omniscience, it is easily shaken. How can it be called concentration?
Below, based on specific practices, specific difficulties are raised against the general.
If one can attain samÄdhi through a single practice, he establishes a principle.
The other practices are also not, he refutes the other's meaning.ğŸ”½If it is not samÄdhi and not omniscience, he raises difficulties regarding concentration based on wisdom.
If it is not omniscience, how can it be called concentration? This is a difficulty regarding concentration based on wisdom.
Wisdom and equanimity are like this. The previous is raised as a difficulty against the latter.
Although it is said to be like this, if one seeks in detail, there are similarities and differences.

How are the similarities and differences? Based on the ordinary and the sagely, the general is raised as a difficulty against the specific. The three practices are all the same. All sentient beings have the faculty of wisdom and also have the faculty of equanimity. Why speak of cultivating wisdom and equanimity?
Regarding the three practices, each is different.
What are the differences in characteristics?
The previous difficulty states that the mind dwelling on one object in concentration is called samÄdhi, and other conditions are not.
In the difficulty regarding wisdom, knowing all dharmas is called omniscience, but knowing one is not.
What are the difficulties in characteristics?
If knowing all is called omniscience, knowing one should not be.
If knowing one is not, the concentration it relies on is not called samÄdhi.
If it is not samÄdhi, how can it be called wisdom?
In the difficulty regarding abandonment, the abandonment of concentration is difficult and the same as wisdom, and the abandonment of wisdom is difficult and the same as concentration.

Below, the Buddha answers, first explaining the later difficulty and answering the first question.ğŸ”½In explaining the difficulty, first resolving the later difficulty of grasping the specific and the general, and then explaining the first difficulty of grasping the general and the specific.
In the difficulty of grasping the specific, first resolving the earlier difficulty of comprehensively grasping above, first citing and directly refuting, why below explaining.
The same is true for the other conditions and one-pointedness of mind means that according to their distinctions, each abides in one object. Why are they not samÄdhi?
Practice is also like this classifies and explains the later set of distinctions in practice.
The above explains and resolves the objection of distinguishing the specific, and below it explains and removes the objection of distinguishing the general.
First, regarding samÄdhi, The statement that it exists before birth is not so is a direct refutation of the objection.
The reason is explained below.

SamÄdhi is called good samÄdhi distinguishes it from evil and indeterminate states. Beings do not have it distinguishes sages from ordinary people. Why do you say... is the concluding statement of the objection.
Because it abides before uses the previous samÄdhi to illustrate wisdom and equanimity, which are not the same as the two mental factors of wisdom and equanimity possessed by all beings.
The above section explains and resolves the later objection. Below it explains the initial question.
The previous question was about the characteristics of samÄdhi, wisdom, and equanimity. The Buddha now clarifies them.
Here, one should first extensively explain the three meanings and then interpret the text. The meanings are as in the separate chapters.
In the text, there are eight sections:
First, distinguishing based on objects;
Second, distinguishing based on people;
Third, distinguishing based on characteristics, which can also be called distinguishing based on ability;
Fourth, distinguishing the characteristics through expansion and contraction;
Fifth, clarifying the purpose of cultivation;
Sixth, clarifying the mutual assistance of the characteristics;
Seventh, distinguishing the three practices based on the three samÄdhi gates;
Eighth, distinguishing the differences based on the time of cultivation.

In the first section, there are many distinctions in objects, as explained in the separate chapters. However, for now, let us discuss it based on phenomena and principles. Phenomena and principles encompass everything, so let us discuss it based on form.
Calming the mind in the matter of form is called samÄdhi, like the eight dhyÄnas in the world.
If one can contemplate form as either permanent or impermanent, etc., it is called the characteristic of wisdom.
Equally cultivating samÄdhi and wisdom, and abandoning biased practices, is called the characteristic of equanimity.
In this, the first is the principle, next is the analogy, and finally is the combination.
The second, distinguishing by person, can be understood.
The third, distinguishing by characteristics, has five phrases.
The first phrase can extinguish coarse and heavy afflictions, the second can remove coarse and heavy evil karma, these two are the beginning of cultivation;
The third can stop light and subtle karma, the last two can be free from light and subtle afflictions, these three are the end of practice.
For this reason and below, concludes the six phrases in wisdom.
Called right view is the true view of the truth of ultimate reality, also called thorough view is the thorough view of the conventional truth of the world.
Able to see, able to see everywhere expands on the right view, able to see the principle, knowing exhaustively is called everywhere.
The successive distinct characteristics expands on the thorough view, knowing the Dharma without confusion is called successive view.
Following the different names of the Dharma is called distinct characteristic view.
This is called concludes.

In the four phrases on abandonment, it is called equality because samÄdhi and prajÃ±Ä are cultivated equally. It is also called non-disputation because one abandons biased practices. These two are discussed in terms of samÄdhi and prajÃ±Ä.

It is also called non-observation because one does not observe existence or non-existence. It is also called non-practice because one does not practice existence or non-existence. These two are discussed in terms of suchness.
This is called... is the concluding summary.
In the fourth section on combining and distinguishing the characteristics, it only discusses samÄdhi and prajÃ±Ä.
In the gradual increase in numbers of samÄdhi, it is first divided into two, with two approaches:
